statements.name: PROC PRINT
statements.description: Prints observations in a SAS data set using some or all of the variables.

arguments.name: BLANKLINE=
arguments.description: writes a blank line after n observations.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the observation number after which SAS inserts a blank line.

arguments.name: COUNT=
arguments.description: specifies the observation number after which SAS inserts a blank line.

arguments.name: STYLE=
arguments.description: specifies the style attribute to use for the blank line.

arguments.name: CONTENTS=
arguments.description: specifies text for the links in the table of contents.

arguments.name: link-text
arguments.description: specifies text to use in the table of contents.

arguments.name: #BYLINE
arguments.description: substitutes the entire BY line without leading or trailing blanks for #BYLINE in the text string. The BY line uses the format variable-name=value.

arguments.name: #BYVAL
arguments.description: substitutes the current value of the specified BY variable for #BYVAL in the text string. Specify the variable with one of these values:

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies a variable by its position in the BY statement. For example, #BYVAL2 specifies the second variable in the BY statement.

arguments.name: BY-variable-name
arguments.description: specifies a variable from the BY statement by its name. For example, #BYVAL(YEAR) specifies the BY variable, YEAR. variable-name is not case sensitive.

arguments.name: #BYVAR
arguments.description: substitutes the name of the BY variable or the label associated with the variable (whatever the BY line would normally display) for #BYVAR in the text string. Specify the variable with one of these values:

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies a variable by its position in the BY statement. For example, #BYVAR2 specifies the second variable in the BY statement.

arguments.name: BY-variable-name
arguments.description: specifies a variable from the BY statement by its name. For example, #BYVAR(SITES) specifies the BY variable, SITES. variable-name is not case sensitive.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: specifies the SAS data set to print.

arguments.name: DOUBLE
arguments.description: writes a blank line between observations.

arguments.name: GRANDTOTAL_LABEL=
arguments.description: displays a label on the grand total line.

arguments.name: HEADING=
arguments.description: controls the orientation of the column headings.

arguments.name: HORIZONTAL
arguments.description: prints all column headings horizontally.

arguments.name: VERTICAL
arguments.description: prints all column headings vertically.

arguments.name: LABEL
arguments.description: specifies to use the variables' labels as column headings.

arguments.name: N
arguments.description: prints the number of observations in the data set, in BY groups, or both and specifies explanatory text to print with the number.

arguments.name: NOOBS
arguments.description: suppresses the column in the output that identifies each observation by number.

arguments.name: OBS=
arguments.description: specifies a column heading for the column that identifies each observation by number.

arguments.name: ROUND
arguments.description: rounds unformatted numeric values to two decimal places.

arguments.name: ROWS=
arguments.description: formats the rows on a page.

arguments.name: PAGE
arguments.description: prints only one row of variables for each observation per page. When you use ROWS=PAGE, PROC PRINT does not divide the page into sections; it prints as many observations as possible on each page. If the observations do not fill the last page of the output, PROC PRINT divides the last page into sections and prints all the variables for the last few observations.

arguments.name: SPLIT=
arguments.description: specifies the split character, which controls line breaks in column headings.

arguments.name: STYLE
arguments.description: specify one or more ODS style overrides to modify the default style element and attributes in a specific area of a report.

arguments.name: location
arguments.description: identifies the part of the report that the STYLE option affects. If location(s) is not specified, PROC PRINT determines the location to where the style override is applied based on the statement, the specified style element, and the style attribute.

arguments.name: style-element-name
arguments.description: is the name of a style element in a style template that is registered with the Output Delivery System. SAS provides some style templates. Users can create their own style templates with the TEMPLATE procedure. See .

arguments.name: style-attribute-specification
arguments.description: describes the style attribute to change. Each style-attribute-specification has this general form:

arguments.name: SUMLABEL
arguments.description: specifies whether to display a label on the summary line for a BY group.

arguments.name: NOSUMLABEL
arguments.description: specifies whether to display a label on the summary line for a BY group.

arguments.name: SUMLABEL=
arguments.description: specifies whether to display a label on the summary line for a BY group.

arguments.name: SUMLABEL
arguments.description: specifies to use the variable label, if it exists, as the label on the summary line in place of the variable name.

arguments.name: NOSUMLABEL
arguments.description: specifies to leave the label on the summary line blank. Alternatively, you can use SUMLABEL="" (two single or double quotation marks with no space between them) to indicate a blank on the summary line.

arguments.name: SUMLABEL=
arguments.description: specifies the text to use as a label on the summary line of a BY group. You can include the #BYVAR and #BYVAL variables in 'label'.

arguments.name: UNIFORM
arguments.description: specifies to use each variable's formatted width as its column width on all pages.

arguments.name: WIDTH=
arguments.description: determines the column width for each variable.

arguments.name: FULL
arguments.description: uses a variable's formatted width as the column width. If the variable does not have a format that explicitly specifies a field width, PROC PRINT uses the default width. For a character variable, the default width is the length of the variable. For a numeric variable, the default width is 12. When you use WIDTH=FULL, the column widths do not vary from page to page.

arguments.name: MINIMUM
arguments.description: uses for each variable the minimum column width that accommodates all values of the variable.

arguments.name: UNIFORM
arguments.description: uses each variable's formatted width as its column width on all pages. If the variable does not have a format that explicitly specifies a field width, PROC PRINT uses the widest data value as the column width. When you specify WIDTH=UNIFORM, PROC PRINT normally needs to read the data set twice. However, if all the variables in the data set have formats that explicitly specify a field width (for example, BEST12. but not BEST.), PROC PRINT reads the data set only once.

arguments.name: UNIFORMBY
arguments.description: formats all columns uniformly within a BY group, using each variable's formatted width as its column width. If the variable does not have a format that explicitly specifies a field width, PROC PRINT uses the widest data value as the column width.

statements.name: ATTRIB
statements.description: Associates a format, informat, label, and length with one or more variables.

arguments.name: variable-list
arguments.description: names the variables that you want to associate with the attributes.

arguments.name: FORMAT=
arguments.description: associates a format with variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: INFORMAT=
arguments.description: associates an informat with variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: associates a label with variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: LENGTH=
arguments.description: specifies the length of variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: TRANSCODE=
arguments.description: specifies whether character variables can be transcoded. Use TRANSCODE=NO to suppress transcoding. Variables with TRANSCODE=NO are not returned.

statements.name: BY
statements.description: Orders the output according to the BY groups.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: specifies the variable that the procedure uses to form BY groups. You can specify more than one variable. If you do not use the NOTSORTED option in the BY statement, then either the observations in the data set must be sorted by all the variables that you specify, or they must be indexed appropriately. Variables in a BY statement are called BY variables.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: specifies that the observations are sorted in descending order by the variable that immediately follows the word DESCENDING in the BY statement.

arguments.name: NOTSORTED
arguments.description: specifies that observations are not necessarily sorted in alphabetic or numeric order. The observations are grouped in another way (for example, chronological order).

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: names one or more variables for SAS to associate with a format. You must specify at least one variable.

arguments.name: format
arguments.description: specifies the format that is listed for writing the values of the variables.

statements.name: ID
statements.description: Identifies observations by using the formatted values of the variables that you list instead of by using observation numbers.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: specifies one or more variables to print instead of the observation number at the beginning of each row of the report.

arguments.name: STYLE
arguments.description: specifies one or more style overrides to use for ID columns created with the ID statement.

arguments.name: text-string
arguments.description: specifies a label of up to 256 bytes.
removes a label from a variable. Enclose a single blank space in quotation marks to remove an existing label. You can remove labels from multiple variables in a single LABEL statement:

statements.name: PAGEBY
statements.description: Controls page ejects that occur before a page is full.

arguments.name: BY-variable
arguments.description: identifies a variable appearing in the BY statement in the PROC PRINT step. If the value of the BY variable changes, or if the value of any BY variable that precedes it in the BY statement changes, PROC PRINT begins printing a new page.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: identifies the numeric variables to total in the report.

arguments.name: STYLE
arguments.description: specifies one or more style overrides to use for cells containing sums that are created with the SUM statement.

statements.name: SUMBY
statements.description: Limits the number of sums that appear in the report.

arguments.name: BY-variable
arguments.description: identifies a variable that appears in the BY statement in the PROC PRINT step. If the value of the BY variable changes, or if the value of any BY variable that precedes it in the BY statement changes, PROC PRINT prints the sums of all variables listed in the SUM statement.

statements.name: VAR
statements.description: Selects variables that appear in the report and determines their order.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: identifies the variables to print. PROC PRINT prints the variables in the order in which you list them.

arguments.name: STYLE
arguments.description: specifies one or more style overrides to use for all columns that are created by a VAR statement.

statements.name: WHERE
statements.description: Subsets the input data set by specifying certain conditions that each observation must meet before it is available for processing.

arguments.name: where-expression
arguments.description: is an arithmetic or logical expression that generally consists of a sequence of operands and operators.

arguments.name: logical-operator
arguments.description: can be AND, AND NOT, OR, or OR NOT.
